info.game_comments:
2004-A Kids Week game 1.
From Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: Our winter is New Zealand's summer, so this man they call "Father Christmas" swelters in his traditional getup

(2, 1).clue: At lunch counters in the U.S., this beverage is sometimes called moo or moo-juice

(3, 1).clue: It's the 2-word term for a country's official patriotic song

(4, 1).clue: Old King Cole called for his pipe, his bowl & 3 of these musicians

(5, 1).clue: The Illinois commemorative quarter depicts the skyline of this, the state's largest city

(6, 1).clue: I'm this, you're glue, everything you say bounces off me & sticks to you

(1, 2).clue: In the Maori language, waka is this type of boat of which Maoris were master builders

(2, 2).clue: Combine root beer & ice cream & you've created one of these beverages

(3, 2).clue: Related to jazz, this "colorful" style of music, typically sad & slow, is often accompanied by harmonica

(4, 2).clue: In later verses, this title woman goes to the alehouse, the tavern & the cobbler, all for her poor dog

(5, 2).clue: You're looking at the back of a U.S. bill; on its face, you'll see the face of this president

(6, 2).clue: Last name of the comic page character seen here

(1, 3).clue: Hawaiians call the 48 contiguous states this; it's also what New Zealanders call South Island

(2, 3).clue: It's the "Official Sports Beverage" of the NFL, the NBA & the PGA

(3, 3).clue: In a symphony orchestra the 4 main groups of instruments are strings, woodwinds, percussion & this

(4, 3).clue: "Jack Sprat could eat no fat, his wife could eat no" this; together "they licked the platter clean"

(5, 3).clue: 1 of 2 non-presidents on the front of U.S. paper currency in general circulation

(6, 3).clue: If you hear laughter, you may be hearing this son of Abraham & Sarah whose name means "laughter"

(1, 4).clue: A New Zealand government building is known as this, for the insect structure it resembles

(2, 4).clue: One of the world's most popular beverages is this drink made by boiling certain shredded leaves in water

(3, 4).clue: It's an interval of 8 successive notes on the scale; C to C, for example

(4, 4).clue: "Mary, Mary quite contrary, how does your garden grow?  With silver bells and" these, "and pretty maids all in a row"

(5, 4).clue: This cabinet department's seal appears on all U.S. paper currency

(6, 4).clue: Your parents hate it when you're this, meaning unreasonably obstinate

(2, 5).clue: When topped with foam, the espresso type of this beverage becomes a cappuccino

(3, 5).clue: He's the composer of the famous march performed here by Grambling University's Tiger Marching Band

(5, 5).clue: A "D" on U.S. coins indicates the coin was minted in Denver; a "P", this city

(6, 5).clue: You use this mark to denote which syllable is stressed

(1, 1).clue: On September 9, 1983 a petition was submitted to Congress asking that the district be made this

(2, 1).clue: A galactic cluster known as the Pleiades is in this constellation known as "The Bull"

(3, 1).clue: The Megabite, which set a world record in 1997 for the largest one of these flown, was 210 feet long including the tails

(4, 1).clue: Discovered as a child by P.T. Barnum, tiny 25" tall Charles Stratton became known as Tom this

(6, 1).clue: A type of time out that sounds like what a puppy has 4 of

(1, 2).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew)  The White House has been known as this "Mansion", also the branch of our government that works here

(2, 2).clue: In 1610 Galileo became the first to find other moons when he saw moons orbiting this giant planet

(3, 2).clue: It's the only even prime number

(4, 2).clue: He was only 9 or 10 when he became Egypt's pharaoh sometime around 1348 B.C.

(6, 2).clue: This word for a period of time away from work or school comes from the Latin word for "to be empty"

(1, 3).clue: The NSO, the National Symphony Orchestra, has been playing at this center since 1971, the year it opened

(2, 3).clue: In 1705 this English astronomer predicted the 1758 return of the comet now named for him

(3, 3).clue: This Jewish festival begins on the eve of the 25th day of Kislev, which in 2004 is December 8, & lasts 8 days

(4, 3).clue: John Smith said that this girl was about 10 when he met her in 1607 (she looked a little older in the Disney movie)

(6, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew on the Yucatan Peninsula)  In Mexico, a small store may close during early afternoon because the owner is taking a nap, called this

(1, 4).clue: In 1846 the District of Columbia gave back about 30 square miles of its area to this state

(2, 4).clue: In 1905 Percival Lowell began a search for this planet, which was discovered in 1930, 14 years after his death

(3, 4).clue: It's the drawer in a refrigerator for storing vegetables, or how it should make your vegetables sound

(4, 4).clue: When he became the heir to the English throne at age 10, he probably had no idea he'd get married 6 times

(6, 4).clue: This single word for a time out implies that you take the time to inhale & exhale

(1, 5).clue: Get off the Metro at Farragut North to visit this society's Explorers Hall

(2, 5).clue: Around 2700 B.C. Thuban was the North Star; today, this is the North Star

(3, 5).clue: This country's official name is Bundesrepublik Deutschland

(4, 5).clue: In 1815, at age 6, this future writer of scary stories moved to Great Britain with his foster family, the Allans

(6, 5).clue: A phrase meaning "stop shouting" got combined into this word for a truce in combat

(0, 0).clue: 2 popular places for swimming in this national park are in Firehole Canyon & at Boiling River
